comment.narrative:
Relevant baseline values to be established during inception phase measure of current extent of land degradation will include but will not be limited to
Land area ha of subzoba with signs of soil erosion
Ha of land area deforested using longterm time series
Liters of water abstraction for agricultural use irrigation per ha distribution map
Soil fertility levels baselines to be established at pilot village level relevant measures to be determined
Level of NRM yields eg crops
Overall 25 decrease in degraded area individual targets to be developed as per established measure during inception period

Total highlysevere degraded land was 16180ha Baseline
Due to better land tenure system introduction of land management improved irrigation system and afforestation the degraded land relatively stabilised and reduced by 11 on crop lands and 12 on open access grazing land converted to community forestwoodlots

description.narrative: 2 Ha of land under new private land tenure arrangements No of villages and area of land covered

comment.narrative: Currently the 1994 Land Proclamation is not applied and 0 ha of land in the Serejeka subzoba are under longterm private ownership tenure
More than 50 of land in the subzoba are under private title following the provisions of the 1994 Land Proclamation
13275 ha of agricultural land are put under the new private land tenure arrangements which belongs to 5 villages

description.narrative: Decrease of population living below the poverty line in Serejeka subzoba

comment.narrative: Currently 66 of the population in Serejeka subzoba live below the poverty line according to the international definition of poverty assessed in xxx through xxx
The poverty rate is reduced to at least 40 in the subzoba

At this stage there is no concrete informationdata available in poverty reduction however proxy estimates in the project area suggests that poverty has reduced slightly due to expansion of irrigation system by 60 increase in agricultural production and other income generating interventions like horticulture sale of vegetables from improved irrigation system and sale of timbers from afforestation interventions

description.narrative: A system of knowledge management KM for SLM is developed and used to achieve SLM through mainstreaming of SLM principles into the regional and national development programs projects strategies policies and legislation
10 Zoba and subzoba annual budgets in target area include allocations for replicationadoption of SLM models to new villages and for the extension and implementation of SLM activities

comment.narrative: Baseline information on Zobas and sub zobas budget allocated to SLM practices will be determined during the inception phase
40 increment on their budget for SLM practices

There is no quantitative data allocation of resources for SLM replicationadoption of SLM models However reports Secondary information indicates that the government and the sub region invest on sustainable land management practices such as check dams catchment treatment afforestation and soil and water conservations Sub region allocated 23 million ERN for the establishment of four nursery stations for tree seedling production to be distributed to communities in the project area The nursery can produce over 12 million seedlings a year Sub Zoba covers all related costsexpenses of production and transportation

description.narrative: 7 Increased knowledge about SLM practices amongst all project key stakeholders SLM platform members

50 of population in 28 pilot villages and 100 of all extension personnel reach knowledge and awareness target set after baseline survey

1696053220 32 community members participated in sustainable land management awareness programmes in all 28 villages and 65 of extension personnel received trainings and acquired good knowledge and awareness of sustainable Land management principles Besides practical and theoretical training on basic GPS application was conducted for 10 days for 23 staffs from Ministry of Agriculture who are directly involved in the land distribution and mapping

description.narrative: 8 Coordinated SLM KM platform operational and self sustaining

A minimum of 7 SLMKM platforms established 1 national 3 regional and 3 subregional

comment.narrative:
Currently no communitylevel SLM plans are in place
No of villages with functional SLM plans in place

The management of land in Serejeka subzoba is guided by community level SLM plans the Serejeka subzoba constitutes approximately 240000 ha and 28 villages are situated in the subzoba

No of villages with functional SLM plans in place 5 villages out of 28 528 which covers 18 of the total project area are in place with SLM plan
Area ha managed through application of SLM plans Total area covered is 1974ha Crop land 1005ha and community woodlots 970ha this indicates 9 increment from baseline

description.narrative: 5 Ratio of source of household incomes in the 28 pilot villages income from agriculture versus other alternative income sources

comment.narrative: Baseline is established Ratio of source of household incomes in the pilot villages ie income from agriculture versus other alternative income sources follows the following pattern 75 of the source of income is derived from agriculture while 25 comes from off farm employment and remittance
Ratios clearly indicate income diversification as a measure of resilience final targets to be established during inception phase

No quantitative available data for this indicator however the proxy indicators shows that increased income generating activities such as bee keeping expansion of woodlots and sale cash income from dales of timber expansion of irrigated crops Vegetables enhanced diversification of income sources and attributed to increase agricultural productionThe proportion of source of household incomes in the pilot villages from agriculture versus other alternative income sources has shown slight shift from baseline situation Estimated 5 increment is observed

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

1. Amount of water harvested increased from subsurface and microdams with associated pumping and irrigation water distribution facilities. 2. Tonnes of harvest/ production increased. 3. No of policy/plans/strategies recised or developed as a result of policy advocacy activities.

comment.narrative: 1. Due to climate change impact the sub zoba hamelmalo and Habero observed variablity in temprature resulting water stress. 2. In the programme area seasonal and multi-year droughts are more frequent than in the past resulting very low agricultural production. 3.Existing policies and plans not uptodated.
- Two micro dams in sub zoba Habero and Hamelmalo. - Installation of solar home lighting for 750 HH in sub zoba Habero and Hamelmalo - Soil and water conservation

- Construction of micro dams is underway (80% completed) - Procurement of solar home lighting completed. Solar equipement with all accessories arrived, installation will be completed in January/February 2017. - As part of afforestation and support HH's economically 44000 tree seedlings of high economic importance like acacia and sisal were planted in sub zoba Habero. - 170 quintals of Drought resistant, and early maturing sorghum and pearl millet crops were distributed to 250HH's..

- Construction of one micro dam - Installation of solar home lighting for 750 HH in sub zoba Habero and Hamelmalo - Procurement of raw materials for the construction of energy efficient traditional stoves for 2000HH's - Soil and water conservation - Solar irrigation development - MTR

- The construction of two micro dams with a capacity of 1,000000m3 in Bashari village completed. - Installation of solar home lighting for 750 HH's in Ajerbeb and Tseada Habero villages completed - Mid Term Review (MTR) complted and final report submitted - As part of soil and water conservation 93Km of terraces, 38,030m3 of check-dams, 40ha of land has been put under closure for natural regeneration, and 266,400 tree species have been planted to restore and conserve the upper catchment of newly built micro-dams and other irrigation infrastructures

The project will strengthen the capacity of the NCEW to promot decent work, effective and strong socail dialloge and workers industrial skills to foster tripartite alliance between the governmnet, trud unions and employeers organizations.
capital of a political entity

- Updated curriculum for Geology and Mining engineering - # of experts recruited for the EIT, Orotta School of Medicine and College of Marine Science & Technology

comment.narrative: Existing curriculum for Geology and Mining engineering
Persons from trade unions that comprised of men and women were able gain knowledge on effective leadership, project cycle, negotiation skills as well as human rights and awareness about decent work.

A total of 413 persons from trade unions that comprised 66% men and 34% women were able gain knowledge on effective leadership, project cycle, negotiation skills as well as human rights and awareness about decent work. UNDP created a platform by organizing tripartite meeting among main organizations, (ministry of Labour and Human Welfare, the Eritrea Federation of Employers (EFE) and the National Confederation of Eritrean Workers (NCEW). The three organization Was able discuss the promotion of equal employment opportunity and the Eritrean Labour proclamation, promotion of equal employment opportunity was conducted among the government. In addition to UNDP’s support benefited about 68 individuals to enhance their knowledge on promoting collective agreement, bargaining. About 35% of the participants were women. With the assistance of UNDP the NCEW was able to build the skills and capacities of workers (about 43 (13 women) on promoting occupational safety and health at work place. UNDP supported and capacitated the NCEW to organize international conferences by itself. The NCEW was able to conduct conferences with the International Trade Union in March 2016 jointly with African Regional Organizational of International Trade Union Confederation (ITUC- Africa) and International Trade Confederation (ITUC), and manifestations of its modest efforts to contribute towards the strengthening of international cooperation and unity among trade unions. The conference was very successful in promoting the solidarity of over 35 national, regional and international trade unions for a common cause that promoting a decent work agenda. The symposia has elevated the image
No target for 2017. It is operationally closed project
No target for 2017. It is operationally closed project

Conduct international conference on Eritrean studied

120 research papers were presented in six plenary and 36 panel/parallel sessions and more than 450 participants attended the conference from more than 26 countries including Germany, Italy, USA and Fiji. research and policy papers on a wide range of cross-cutting themes including Eritrea’s foreign policy and regional relations, its post-independence national development, arts and culture, Eritrean history and archaeology and the origins and emergence of Eritrean nationalism.
60 research papers finalized and printed which were presented at International Conference in six plenary and 36 panel/parallel sessions

comment.narrative:
• Mean number of months that households are able to feed themselves from their harvest is between 2 & 4 months (Baseline Survey-Emergency Response Addressing Livelihoods, 2010)
• All the targeted households depend on crops and/or livestock for their source of income
Supporting locust and drought affected population of the NRS with improved seeds.

The emergency response addressing livelihood security for drought and desert locust affected population of the Northern and Southern Red Sea regions has been successfully completed. The intervention has contributed in restoring the traditional productive agricultural activities which have a direct and immediate impact on improving food availability and livelihoods of the affected people. Specifically, the aim of the project was to provide improved seeds and restocking support to the drought and locust affected people to enable them gain lost assets, recover and start normal life. Accordingly, UNDP has supported the hard hit areas of the Northern Red Sea and the Southern Red Sea regions. The target areas were In the Northern Red Sea Sub-zones of Foro (Kebabi Demhina), Gelalo (Kebabi Bada) and Ghinda (Kebabi Dongolo Tahtay and Dongolo Laelay; and in the Southern Red Sea sub-zones of Maekel Denkel (Afambo) and Debub Denkel (Maebele and Alale) and Assab (Menkaekae). The results of the improved seeds distributed in 2015 (43,270kgs) were less than anticipated due to unexpected heavy rain and floods. The premature crops of the season were witnessed by the UNDP/OCHA and ECHO mission during its visit to one of the target areas of the Northern Red Sea, sub-zone of Ghinda, kebabi Dongolo Laelay. The results of the improved seeds distributed to 3121 male beneficiaries are expected to be harvested in February-March next year.
Build soil and water conservation structures on heavily eroded land and gullies created by floods and water run offs - such as dry masonry check dams, gabion, soil bunds, stone bands, and terraces.

description.narrative: Strengthening Capacity for Training, Agricultural/Food Security Research and Outreach Programme in Hamelmalo Agricultural College.

comment.narrative: Low laboratory capacity
Strengthening Hamelmalo Agricultural College with lab equipment and furniture.
Procurement of laboratory equipment and furniture is in process; it will be delivered to the college shortly (Q1 of 2017)
Procurement of laboratory equipment and furniture which was started in 2016 is in progress.

UNDP CO supported the installation of 12 Agricultural Science Laboratories at the Hamelmalo Agricultural College. The laboratory facilities are significantly contributing towards expanding the capacity in agricultural and Natural Resources Practical Research in the country by improving the laboratory facilities for scientists and students to conduct research on key agricultural constraints in food production and natural resources conservation.It is highly expected to contribute to the food security of the country both in quality and quantitiy.

description.narrative: The programme supports the NUEYS and other key stakeholders in training youth and creating employment opportunity
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old
Number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old
Total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created
Number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
Number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
Number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
Extent to which policies, systems and/or institutional measures are in place at the national and sub-national levels to generate and strengthen employment and livelihoods
The Youth employment project is designed to support in creating employment opportunity for the youth
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

• Number of vocational skills training centres supported and/or rehabilitated • Availability of enhanced training materials/manuals • Number trainers upgraded their skills • Number of youth trained in VST and entrepreneurship • Number of self-help small scale enterprises established through the provision of micro credit facilities

comment.narrative: TBD
vulnerable (less privileged) young people trained vocational skills

1060 vulnerable (less privileged) young people have been trained vocational skills as part of human resource development initiative for economic engagement. 58% of the trained young people are females.
Livelihood opportunities of 600 vulnerable youths

Livelihood opportunities of 653 vulnerable youths (80% female) have been enhanced through vocational and entrepreneurship skills for work; and 230 of the youths (77% female) have started their own businesses with micro-credit support from UNDP. The vocational training areas offered were hair dressing, bee keeping, net making, hand craft, poultry, graphics, weaving, camera shooting, pottery, editing .114 young students received bicycles to help them improve their academic performance through saved time and energy in walking to school; and reduce drop-out rates. Strengthened capacity of NUEYS to sustainably deliver trainings on vocational and entrepreneurship skills by upgrading (rehabilitation and equipping of) their Barentu and Keren youth centres as livelihood centres; and expected to train about 200 youths annually from 50 youths before the upgrades

description.narrative: The Stabilization through Youth and Women Empowerment Project intends to develop employment skills and create employment opportunities for vulnerable youth and women for social stabilization
first-order administrative division
policy, planning and administration

Indicator 1: Number of youths trained (Male and Female) Indicator 2: Number of youths trained and received starter-up kits (Male and Female) Indicator 3: Number of youths trained and accessed grants (Male and Female)

comment.narrative: Number of youths trained

700 youths trained in diverse livelihood skill areas
300 of the trained youths receive grants/ starter packs for businesses
250 Youths trained and accessed grants

1) Two youth centers were rehabilitated and equipped, Mendefera (Debub region) and Adi Guadad (Maekel region); and now have improved teaching and learning conditions and opportunities. This is a result of the youth centers being turned into functional youth livelihood centers as required and having the ability to now annually produce graduates four times more than the used to be trained 200 from the vulnerable youth and women population. The capacity of the youth centers was enhanced from 20% to about 80%, the required and intended sufficiency level, for the centers to competently deliver their vocational skills training mandates. Table 1 gives a brief presentation of the capacity enabling undertaken. 2) 618 youths were trained in various vocational skills and entrepreneurship; and are now able to competently conduct manual work in their respective training fields of vocational skills and others are able to start and manage their own businesses. The trained 618 represents a 54% performance exceeding the planned result of 400 vulnerable youths and women acquiring vocational skills. How did we achieve this? About 59% of the trained are females. It can be attributed to girls and women empowerment campaigns and affirmative action of opening up for interests of women in the economic activities. However, the gender representation is still weak in the traditional male dominated vocations such as wood and metal
618 youths were trained in various vocational skills and entrepreneurship; and are now able to competently conduct manual work in their respective training fields of vocational skills and others are able to start and manage their own businesses. The trained 618 represents a 54% performance exceeding the planned result of 400 vulnerable youths and women acquiring vocational skills.
1) 157 youths and women of the VST graduates received business start-up micro-grants in form of cash and materials/ equipment (in kind) from the project resulting in immediate self-empl

-Conduct a joint capacity gap verification exercise for the selected training centers 1 Jan 2017 31 Dec 2017 -Training centers renovated and equipped with livelihood training equipment 1 Jan 2017 31 Dec 2017 •Establishment of a youth business support scheme to create jobs and livelihood opportunities for 400 marginalized and vulnerable youth
